text: primary functions package begin get_ listed : get_ces() - accesses data Current Employment Statistics (CES) program state metropolitan area levels. provides employer-based estimates employment, wages, hours worked. “SM” database. Enhanced specialized dataset options including seasonally adjusted series, real earnings data, complete historical data optimal performance. get_laus() - accesses data Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) program regional, state, several sub-state levels. localized version Current Population Survey (CPS) used drive household-based estimates employment unemployment. “LA” database. Note volume data , several different geographies may specified pull appropriate data file BLS. information Local Area Unemployment Statistics, please visit https://www.bls.gov/lau/. get_oews() - access Occupational Employment Wage Statistics (OEWS) data. data provides survey-based estimates employment wages occupation state sub-state levels. “OE” database. Note current-year data available OEWS database, built time series. information Occupational Employment Wage Statistics, please visit https://www.bls.gov/oes/. get_salt() - data actually loaded within time.series folder, instead sourced https://www.bls.gov/lau/stalt.htm. Alternative Measures Labor Underutilization States 12-month averages built CPS data provide expansive restrictive definitions unemployment measure labor force, known U1 U6. function also includes optional geometry argument. set TRUE, use tigris::states() tigris::shift_geometry() provide state polygons convenient mapping output. information Alternative Measures data, please visit https://www.bls.gov/lau/stalt.htm. functions download series files time.series database BLS, join files together, perform simple filtering streamlining prepare data time series analysis. title: Introduction to BLSloadR
text: enhanced CES functions provide significant performance improvements: State filtering: Download specific states instead 50+ states (90% faster) Industry filtering: Focus specific industries like retail, manufacturing, construction Current year option: Get recent data (2006-present) instead complete historical series National datasets: Choose specialized national datasets (seasonally adjusted, real earnings) faster downloads example: - Complete CES download: 60+ seconds ~5.6M rows - Single state (MA): ~3.5 seconds ~210K rows - Seasonally adjusted national: ~3.7 seconds ~392K rows

Collective Bargaining-Private Sector cc - Employer Costs Employee Compensation (SIC 1986-2003) cd - Occupational Injuries Illness - Characteristics Data (SIC) ce - Employment, Hours, Earnings-National (NAICS) cf - Census Fatal Occupational Injuries (1992-2002) ch - Nonfatal cases involving days away work: selected charachteristics ci - Employment Cost Index (NAICS) cm - Employer Costs Employee Compensation (NAICS) cs - Occupational Injuries Illnesses - Characteristics Data cu - Consumer Price Index-Urban Consumers (Current Series) cw - Consumer Price Index-Urban Wage Earners Clerical Workers cx - Consumer Expenditure Survey eb - Employee Benefits Survey (1979 - 2006) ec - Employment Cost Index (SIC 1975 - 2005) ee - Employment, Hours, Earnings-National (SIC) ei - International Price Index fi - Census Fatal Occupational Injuries fm - Marital Family Labor Force Statistics fw - Census Fatal Occupational Injuries gg - Green Goods Services gp - Geographic Profile hc - Occupational Injuries Illness - Characteristics Data (NAICS) hs - Occupational Injury Illness Rates (based 1972 SIC codes) ii - Occupational Injuries Illnesses Industry Data - International Labor Statistics ip - Industry Productivity Costs jl - Job Openings Labor Turnover Survey (SIC) jt - Job Openings Labor Turnover Survey (NAICS) la - Local Area Unemployment Statistics le - Weekly Hourly Earnings Data Current Population li - Department Store Inventory Price Index ln - Labor Force Statistics Current Population Survey (NAICS) lu - Union Affiliation Data Current Population Survey ml - Mass Layoff Statistics mp - Major Sector Multifactor Productivity Index mu - Consumer Price Index-Urban Consumers (Old Series) mw - Consumer Price Index-Urban Wage Earners Clerical Workers nb - National Compensation Survey nc - National Compensation Survey (SIC 1997-2006) nd - Producer Price Index Revision-Discontinued Series (NAICS) nl - National Longitudinal Survey nw - National Compensation Survey (NAICS) oe - Occupation Employment Statistics - Occupational Requirements Survey pc - Producer Price Index Revision-Current Series pd - Producer Price Index Revision-Discontinued Series (SIC) pr - Major Sector Productivity Costs Index sa - State Area Employment, Hours, Earnings (SIC) sh - Occupational Injury Illness Rates (based 1987 SIC codes) si - Occupational Injury Illness Rates (2002 data) sm - State Area Employment, Hours, Earnings (NAICS) su - Chained CPI-Urban Consumers wd - Producer Price Index Commodity - Discontinued Series wm - Modeled Wage Estimates wp - Producer Price Index - Commodities ws - Work Stoppage Data

what: Step 2: Renaming, Filtering, and Narrowing the Table
title: Working with LAUS Data
text: Next, rename columns, select clarify values need, assign R-friendly column names data make easier work . allow us pivot data, allowing easier manipulation columns.
code: bls_state_table <- bls_import |>   rename("state" = "area_text",          "measure" = "measure_text") |>   filter(state != "Puerto Rico") |>   select(date, state, measure, value) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = measure, values_from = value) |>   rename("ur" = "unemployment rate",          "unemployment" = "unemployment",          "employment" = "employment",          "labor_force" = "labor force",          "epr" = "employment-population ratio",          "lfpr" = "labor force participation rate")  head(bls_state_table,10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 8 #>    date       state      ur unemployment employment labor_force   epr  lfpr #>    <date>     <chr>   <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 1976-01-01 Alabama 0.067        98903    1387606     1486509 0.533 0.571 #>  2 1976-02-01 Alabama 0.066        98677    1387267     1485944 0.532 0.569 #>  3 1976-03-01 Alabama 0.066        97869    1388303     1486172 0.531 0.568 #>  4 1976-04-01 Alabama 0.065        96761    1392012     1488773 0.531 0.568 #>  5 1976-05-01 Alabama 0.064        96242    1396244     1492486 0.532 0.568 #>  6 1976-06-01 Alabama 0.065        96744    1400036     1496780 0.532 0.569 #>  7 1976-07-01 Alabama 0.065        98225    1402922     1501147 0.532 0.569 #>  8 1976-08-01 Alabama 0.067       100273    1405216     1505489 0.532 0.57  #>  9 1976-09-01 Alabama 0.068       102302    1407784     1510086 0.532 0.571 #> 10 1976-10-01 Alabama 0.069       104185    1410640     1514825 0.532 0.572

title: Working with LAUS Data
text: access full time series states, can move away comparing single state national trend. Instead, can compare state--state, allows nuanced context showing common uncommon single state’s experience across nation. , calculate 20th, 50th (median), 80th percentiles.
code: bls_state_table <- bls_state_table |>   pivot_longer(3:8, names_to = "measure", values_to = "value") |>   group_by(date, measure) |>   mutate(     pct_20 = quantile(value, 0.2, na.rm = TRUE),     pct_80 = quantile(value, 0.8, na.rm = TRUE),     median = median(value, na.rm = TRUE)   ) |>    ungroup()  head(bls_state_table,10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 7 #>    date       state   measure            value     pct_20      pct_80     median #>    <date>     <chr>   <chr>              <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> #>  1 1976-01-01 Alabama ur                 0.067      0.058       0.092    6.7 e-2 #>  2 1976-01-01 Alabama unemployment   98903      29410      187753        9.50e+4 #>  3 1976-01-01 Alabama employment   1387606     364957     2426320        1.20e+6 #>  4 1976-01-01 Alabama labor_force  1486509     390460     2595504        1.30e+6 #>  5 1976-01-01 Alabama epr                0.533      0.554       0.618    5.84e-1 #>  6 1976-01-01 Alabama lfpr               0.571      0.597       0.653    6.31e-1 #>  7 1976-02-01 Alabama ur                 0.066      0.058       0.092    6.6 e-2 #>  8 1976-02-01 Alabama unemployment   98677      29414      187838        9.50e+4 #>  9 1976-02-01 Alabama employment   1387267     364611     2425263        1.20e+6 #> 10 1976-02-01 Alabama labor_force  1485944     390099     2594800        1.30e+6

what: Step 4: Narrowing the Data for Display
title: Working with LAUS Data
text: Since now comparative measures across states, can start looking want compare. , look four options: national ranking current Unemployment Rate current Labor Force Participation Rate, comparison trend single state range experiences states time measures. also add column highlight Nevada, state interested highlighting.
code: selected_state <- "Nevada"  bls_current <- bls_state_table |>    filter(date == max(date)) |>    mutate(is_st = if_else(state == selected_state, TRUE, FALSE))  bls_ts <- bls_state_table |>    filter(state == selected_state)

what: Step 3: Exploring the Data with Tables
title: Working with OEWS Data
text: Now data set can easily summarize work . observation single row (occupation place), columns provide information observation (employment level, wage bands, employment concentration). Let’s start simple, create quick table shows spread employment hourly wages state. , easily look detailed occupations, Standard Occupational Classification code used OEWS includes major groups detailed occupations. Working list, can filter data set particular occupation gain insights employment wage trends. ’ll also include location quotient, help us explore whether states unusually high concentration employment occupation. can also explore uniqueness occupation, seeing concentration area varies compared concentration nationally using location quotient. location quotient (LQ) defined ratio employment occupation area total employment area, divided ratio employment occupation United States total employment United States. means higher LQ indicates higher concentration employment area compared concentration employment occupation country. LQarea,occupation=Employmentoccupation areaEmploymenttotal areaEmploymentoccupation U.S.Employmenttotal U.S. \text{LQ}_{area,occupation} =  \frac{\dfrac{Employment_{\text{occupation area}}}{Employment_{\text{total area}}}}      {\dfrac{Employment_{\text{occupation U.S.}}}{Employment_{\text{total U.S.}}}}
code: estimate_year <- unique(western_states$year)  western_states |>    filter(occupation_name == "All Occupations") |> # Total for All Occupations   select(area_name, Employment, `Hourly 10th percentile wage`, `Hourly 25th percentile wage`, `Hourly median wage`, `Hourly 75th percentile wage`, `Hourly 90th percentile wage`) |>    gt() |>    fmt_number(columns = Employment, decimals = 0) |>    fmt_currency(columns = contains("Hourly")) |>    cols_label("area_name" = "State") |>    tab_header(title = "OEWS Employment Statistics for All Occupations",              subtitle = paste0("Western United States, ",estimate_year)) western_states |>    select(occupation_code, occupation_name) |>    distinct() |>    filter(substr(occupation_code,1,2) == "35") |>    gt() western_states |>    filter(occupation_name == "Cooks, Fast Food") |>    select(area_name, Employment, `Hourly 10th percentile wage`, `Hourly 25th percentile wage`, `Hourly median wage`, `Hourly 75th percentile wage`, `Hourly 90th percentile wage`, `Location Quotient`) |>    gt() |>    fmt_number(columns = Employment, decimals = 0) |>    fmt_currency(columns = contains("Hourly")) |>    cols_label("area_name" = "State") |>    tab_header(title = "OEWS Employment Statistics for Fast Food Cooks",              subtitle = paste0("Western United States, ",estimate_year)) western_states |>    select(area_name, occupation_name, `Location Quotient`) |>    arrange(-`Location Quotient`) |>    head(20) |>    gt()

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: BLSloadR package provides two main functions accessing Current Employment Statistics (CES) data Bureau Labor Statistics: get_ces() - State metropolitan area CES data get_national_ces() - National CES data functions enhanced powerful filtering options significantly improve download performance provide targeted data access.

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: diving data downloads, can explore available options using helper functions:
code: # Explore state-level CES options show_ces_options() #> === BLS Current Employment Statistics (CES) Filtering Options === #>  #> AVAILABLE STATES (53 total): #>    AL, AK, AZ, AR, CA, CO, CT, DE, DC, FL  #>    GA, HI, ID, IL, IN, IA, KS, KY, LA, ME  #>    MD, MA, MI, MN, MS, MO, MT, NE, NV, NH  #>    NJ, NM, NY, NC, ND, OH, OK, OR, PA, PR  #>    RI, SC, SD, TN, TX, UT, VT, VA, VI, WA  #>    WV, WI, WY  #>  #> AVAILABLE INDUSTRY FILTERS (24 total): #>   current_year             : Recent data across all industries (2006-present) #>   total_nonfarm            : Total non-farm employment (all industries, all years) #>   total_nonfarm_statewide  : Total non-farm employment (statewide level) #>   total_private            : Total private sector employment #>   goods_producing          : Goods-producing industries #>   service_providing        : Service-providing industries #>   private_service_providing: Private service-providing industries #>   mining_logging           : Mining and logging #>   mining_logging_construction: Mining, logging, and construction #>   construction             : Construction #>   manufacturing            : Manufacturing #>   durable_goods            : Durable goods manufacturing #>   nondurable_goods         : Non-durable goods manufacturing #>   trade_trans_utilities    : Trade, transportation, and utilities #>   wholesale_trade          : Wholesale trade #>   retail_trade             : Retail trade #>   trans_utilities          : Transportation and utilities #>   information              : Information services #>   financial_activities     : Financial activities #>   prof_business_services   : Professional and business services #>   edu_health_services      : Education and health services #>   leisure_hospitality      : Leisure and hospitality #>   other_services           : Other services #>   government               : Government #> USAGE EXAMPLES: #>   # Specific states (all industries, all years) #>   ces_states <- get_ces(states = c('MA', 'NY', 'CT')) #>  #>   # Specific industry (all states, 2007-present) #>   ces_manufacturing <- get_ces(industry_filter = 'manufacturing') #>  #>   # Current year data (all states and industries, 2006-present) #>   ces_current <- get_ces(current_year_only = TRUE) #>  #>   # Complete dataset (all states, industries, and years - slowest) #>   ces_all <- get_ces() #>  #> Performance: Filtering reduces download time by 50-90% vs. full dataset! #> Note: Parameters are mutually exclusive - choose only one filtering option. # Explore national CES options show_national_ces_options() #> === BLS National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Dataset Options === #>  #> AVAILABLE DATASETS (4 options): #>    all_data :  Complete national CES dataset - all series and full history  #>    current_seasonally_adjusted :  Seasonally adjusted all-employee series only (faster download)  #>    real_earnings_all_employees :  Real earnings data (1982-84 dollars) for all employees  #>    real_earnings_production :  Real earnings data (1982-84 dollars) for production employees  #>  #> USAGE EXAMPLES: #>   # Complete dataset (largest file, ~340MB) #>   ces_complete <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = 'all_data') #>  #>   # Seasonally adjusted data only (faster download) #>   ces_seasonal <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = 'current_seasonally_adjusted') #>  #>   # Real earnings for all employees #>   ces_earnings_all <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = 'real_earnings_all_employees') #>  #>   # Real earnings for production employees #>   ces_earnings_prod <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = 'real_earnings_production') #>  #> Performance: Specialized datasets reduce download time significantly! #> Note: All options include metadata files for context and labels.

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: simplest way get state CES data default settings:
code: # Get all available state CES data (this can be quite large!) ces_all <- get_ces()

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: much faster downloads, use filtering options:
code: # Get data for specific states only (much faster!) ces_northeast <- get_ces(   states = c("MA", "CT", "RI", "NH", "VT", "ME"),   suppress_warnings = FALSE )  print(paste("Downloaded", nrow(ces_northeast), "rows")) #> [1] "Downloaded 647766 rows" print(paste("Unique states:", length(unique(ces_northeast$area_text)))) #> [1] "Unique states: 0" # Get data for specific industries only ces_retail <- get_ces(   industry_filter = "retail_trade",   suppress_warnings = FALSE )  print(paste("Downloaded", nrow(ces_retail), "rows")) #> [1] "Downloaded 318249 rows" print("Available industries in this dataset:") #> [1] "Available industries in this dataset:" print(head(unique(ces_retail$industry_text), 10)) #> NULL

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: recent data :
code: # Get recent data (2006 to present) ces_current <- get_ces(   current_year_only = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = FALSE )  print(paste("Date range:", min(ces_current$date), "to", max(ces_current$date))) #> [1] "Date range: 2006-01-01 to 2025-09-01" print(paste("Dataset size:", nrow(ces_current), "rows")) #> [1] "Dataset size: 5607093 rows"

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: national CES function offers four specialized datasets optimal performance:
code: # Get seasonally adjusted data only (fastest download) ces_seasonal <- get_national_ces(   dataset_filter = "current_seasonally_adjusted",   suppress_warnings = FALSE )  print(paste("Seasonally adjusted data:", nrow(ces_seasonal), "rows")) #> [1] "Seasonally adjusted data: 392253 rows" # Get real earnings data for all employees ces_earnings <- get_national_ces(   dataset_filter = "real_earnings_all_employees",   suppress_warnings = FALSE )  print(paste("Real earnings data:", nrow(ces_earnings), "rows")) #> [1] "Real earnings data: 514016 rows" print("Sample of data types included:") #> [1] "Sample of data types included:" print(head(unique(ces_earnings$data_type_text), 5)) #> [1] "AVERAGE WEEKLY EARNINGS OF ALL EMPLOYEES, 1982-1984 DOLLARS" #> [2] "AVERAGE HOURLY EARNINGS OF ALL EMPLOYEES, 1982-1984 DOLLARS"

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: Let’s create simple analysis using national data:
code: # Get recent employment data recent_employment <- ces_seasonal |>   filter(     data_type_text == "All employees, thousands, seasonally adjusted",     supersector_name %in% c("Total nonfarm", "Manufacturing", "Construction",                            "Professional and business services", "Government"),     date >= as.Date("2020-01-01")   ) |>   select(date, supersector_name, value)  # Plot employment trends recent_employment |>   ggplot(aes(x = date, y = value, color = supersector_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   labs(     title = "Employment Trends by Supersector (2020-Present)",     subtitle = "Seasonally Adjusted Employment (thousands)",     x = "Date",     y = "Employment (thousands)",     color = "Supersector"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(     legend.position = "bottom",     legend.title = element_text(size = 10),     plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold")   ) +   guides(color = guide_legend(nrow = 2))

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: enhanced filtering options provide significant performance improvements: Performance Comparison CES Download Options

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: Always start filtered data prototype analysis:
code: # Start with a small subset test_data <- get_ces(states = "MA")  # Develop your analysis code my_analysis <- test_data |>   filter(data_type_text == "All employees, thousands, seasonally adjusted") |>   # ... your analysis code ...  # Then scale up if needed full_data <- get_ces(states = c("MA", "CT", "RI", "NH", "VT", "ME"))

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: Discover available options downloading:
code: # See what states are available available_states <- list_ces_states()  # See what industries you can filter by available_industries <- list_ces_industries(show_descriptions = TRUE)

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: Select appropriate dataset needs:
code: # For quick national employment trends quick_national <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = "current_seasonally_adjusted")  # For wage analysis wage_data <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = "real_earnings_all_employees")  # For state comparisons state_data <- get_ces(states = c("CA", "TX", "NY", "FL"))

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: must download large datasets:
code: # Use return_diagnostics to monitor the download large_data <- get_ces(   current_year_only = TRUE,   return_diagnostics = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = FALSE )  # Check for any issues print_bls_warnings(large_data)  # Extract the data final_data <- get_bls_data(large_data)

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: Keep BLS metadata columns detailed analysis:
code: detailed_data <- get_ces(   states = "MA",   simplify_table = FALSE  # Keeps all metadata columns )

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: Include annual average data (M13 period):
code: with_annual <- get_national_ces(   monthly_only = FALSE  # Includes annual averages )

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: Get data without transformations:
code: raw_data <- get_ces(   states = "MA",   transform = FALSE  # No ratio/thousands conversions )

title: Working with CES Data: Enhanced Features and Performance
text: enhanced get_ces() get_national_ces() functions provide: 90%+ reduction download times smart filtering Flexible options states, industries, time periods Consistent API design across functions Helper functions easy discovery available options Comprehensive documentation examples improvements make BLS employment data accessible practical routine analysis maintaining full power flexibility needed comprehensive research.

title: Download Time Series Data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics
text: BLSloadR packages designed streamline access time series database downloads U.S. Bureau Labor Statistics, made available https://download.bls.gov/pub/time.series/. focused accessing series frequently used states get state-level estimates, includes load_bls_dataset() bls_overview() functions provide generalized access databases website within R environment.

title: Download Time Series Data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics
text: BLSloadR can installed CRAN running install.packages("BLSloadR"). primary functions package begin get_ listed : -get_ces() - accesses data Current Employment Statistics (CES) program state metropolitan area levels. provides employer-based estimates employment, wages, hours worked. “SM” database. -get_national_ces() - accesses national data CES program national level, include state-level breakouts. “CE” database. -get_laus() - accesses data Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) program regional, state, several sub-state levels. localized version Current Population Survey (CPS) used drive household-based estiamtes employment unemployment. “LA” database. Note volume data , several different geographies may specified pull appropriate data file BLS. -get_oews() - access Occupational Employment Wage Statistics (OEWS) data. data provides survey-based estimates employmen wages occupation state sub-state levels. “OE” database. Note current-year data available OEWS database, built time series. -get_salt() - data actually loated within time.series folder, instead sourced https://www.bls.gov/lau/stalt.htm. Alternative Measures Labor Underutilization States 12-month averages built CPS data provide expansive restrictive definitions unemployment measure labor force, known U1 U6. function also includes optional geometry argument. set TRUE, use tigris::states() tigris::shift_geometry() provide state polygons convenient mapping output.

title: Download Time Series Data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics

Use Caution! BLS data structures always consistent. may anomalies structure individual databases, missing column headers, degrade ability function read data.

title: Display BLS Dataset Overview — bls_overview

title: Display BLS Dataset Overview — bls_overview
code: bls_overview(   series_id,   display_method = "viewer",   base_url = "https://download.bls.gov/pub/time.series" )

title: Display BLS Dataset Overview — bls_overview
text: series_id Character string. BLS series identifier (e.g., "ln", "cu", "ap") display_method Character string. display overview: "viewer" (default), "console", "popup" base_url Character string. Base URL BLS data (default uses official BLS site)

title: Display BLS Dataset Overview — bls_overview
text: Invisibly returns text content. Function called use viewer, console, popup, depending 'display_method' argument.

title: Display BLS Dataset Overview — bls_overview
code: # \donttest{ # Display labor force statistics overview bls_overview("ln")  # Display consumer price index overview   bls_overview("cu")  # Display in console instead of viewer bls_overview("ln", display_method = "console") #>  #> === BLS Dataset Overview: LN === #> Source: https://download.bls.gov/pub/time.series/ln/ln.txt #> ==================================================  #>  #> LABOR FORCE STATISTICS FROM THE CURRENT POPULATION SURVEY (LN database) #> 				ln.txt #>  #> Section Listing #>  #> 1. Survey Definition #> 2. Flat files listed in the survey directory. #> 3. Time series, series file, data file, & mapping file definitions and relationships #> 4. Series file format and field definitions #> 5. Data file format and field definitions #> 6. Mapping file formats and field definitions #>  #>  #> ================================================================================ #> Section 1 - Survey Definition #> ================================================================================ #>  #> The following is a definition of: LABOR FORCE STATISTICS FROM THE CURRENT POPULATION SURVEY (LN) #>  #> Survey Description:    #>  #> The Current Population Survey (CPS) is a sample survey of the population 16 years of age and over.   #> The survey is conducted each month by the U.S. Census Bureau for the Bureau of Labor Statistics and provides  #> comprehensive data on the labor force, the employed, and the unemployed, classified by such characteristics  #> as age, sex, race, family relationship, marital status, occupation, and industry attachment.  The information  #> is collected by trained interviewers from a sample of about 60,000 households. Sample areas are chosen to  #> represent all counties and independent cities in the United States, with coverage in 50 States and the District of  #> Columbia.  The data collected are based on the activity or status reported for the calendar week including the  #> 12th of the month.   #>  #> Summary Data Available: CPS data are available for the civilian, noninstitutional population age 16  #> and older and various detailed groups, with estimates available by age, race, sex, Hispanic or Latino #> ethnicity, employment status, occupation, industry, class of worker, educational attainment, telework status, #> and other characteristics. #>  #> Frequency of observations: CPS data are collected each month, and monthly estimates are presented in the Employment  #> Situation News Release. Some data series are available as quarterly or annual averages. #>  #> Data characteristics: Data include counts (presented in thousands) and rates such as the unemploment #> rate, labor force participation rate, and employment-population ratio. #>  #> Updating schedule: Updates are available with the issuance of the monthly #> Employment Situation news release. #>  #>  #> ================================================================================ #> Section 2 - Flat files listed in the survey directory. #> ================================================================================ #>  #> The following CPS labor force files are on the BLS internet in the  #> sub-directory pub/time.series/ln: #>  #>        ln.absn			- Absence codes				mapping file #>        ln.activity		- Activity codes       			mapping file #>        ln.ages			- Age group codes   			mapping file #>        ln.born			- Nativity/Citizenship codes   		mapping file #>        ln.cert			- Certification codes			mapping file #>        ln.chld			- Presence of children codes		mapping file #>        ln.class			- Class of worker codes			mapping file #>        ln.data.1.AllData	- All data 				data file #>        ln.disa			- Disability codes     			mapping file #>        ln.duration 		- Duration codes        		mapping file #>        ln.education 		- Education codes 			mapping file #>        ln.entr 			- Entrance to labor force codes 	mapping file #>        ln.expr	 		- Work experience codes			mapping file #>        ln.footnote 		- Footnote codes			mapping file #>        ln.hheader 		- Head of household codes		mapping file #>        ln.hour	 		- Hours worked codes			mapping file #>        ln.indy	 		- Industry codes			mapping file #>        ln.jdes	 		- Want a job codes			mapping file #>        ln.lfst	 		- Labor force status codes		mapping file #>        ln.look	 		- Job seeker codes			mapping file #>        ln.mari	 		- Marital status codes			mapping file #>        ln.mjhs	 		- Multiple jobholder codes		mapping file #>        ln.occupation 		- Occupation codes			mapping file #>        ln.orig	 		- Hispanic or Latino origin codes	mapping file #>        ln.pcts	 		- Percentage codes			mapping file #>        ln.periodicity 		- Periodicity codes			mapping file #>        ln.race	 		- Race codes				mapping file #>        ln.rjnw	 		- Absence reason codes			mapping file #>        ln.rnlf	 		- Job search codes			mapping file #>        ln.rwns	 		- Part time reason codes		mapping file #>        ln.seasonal 		- Seasonal adjustment codes		mapping file #>        ln.seek	 		- Job seeker codes			mapping file #>        ln.series		- All series with beginning and end dates #>        ln.sexs	 		- Sex codes				mapping file #>        ln.tdat	 		- Data type codes			mapping file #>        ln.tlwk	 		- Telework codes			mapping file #>        ln.txt			- General information #>        ln.vets	 		- Veteran status codes			mapping file #>        ln.wkst	 		- Work status codes			mapping file #> 	 #> ================================================================================ #> Section 3 - Time series, series file, data file, & mapping file definitions and relationships #> ================================================================================ #> The definition of a time series, its relationship to and the interrelationship #> among series, data and mapping files is detailed below: #>  #> A time series refers to a set of data observed over an extended period of time #> over consistent time intervals (i.e. monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, annually). #> CPS time series data are available as monthly estimates, or as quarterly or annual averages. #> Not seasonally adjusted data are considered final when published. At the end of each calendar #> year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) reestimates the seasonal factors for the CPS series  #> by including another full year of data in the estimation process. Following this annual reestimation,  #> BLS revises the historical seasonally adjusted data for the previous 5 years. #>  #> The flat files are organized such that data users are provided with the following #> set of files to use in their efforts to interpret data files: #>  #> a)  a series file (only one series file per database) #> b)  mapping files #> c)  data files #>  #> The series file contains series identification codes that serve to uniquely identify  #> time series within the database, along with their titles and attributes (age, sex, race,  #> occupation, industry, etc.). Additionally, the series file also contains the following  #> series-level information: #>  #> a) the period and year corresponding to the first data observation  #> b) the period and year corresponding to the most recent data observation  #> c) characteristics of the series corresponding to values in the mapping files #>  #> The mapping files are definition files that contain explanatory text  #> descriptions that correspond to information contained within the series file. #>  #> The data file contains one line of data for each observation period pertaining  #> to a specific time series.  Each line contains a reference to the following: #>  #> a) a series identification code #> b) year in which data is observed #> c) period for which data is observed (M01 to M12 indicate monthly data,  #> A01 and M13 indicate annual averages, and Q01, Q01, Q03, Q04 indicate quarterly averages) #> d) value #> e) footnote code (if available) #>  #> For series that have monthly data, M13 indicates annual averages. For series that do #> not have monthly data, A01 indicates annual averages. #>  #> ================================================================================ #> Section 4 - Series file format and field definitions #> ================================================================================ #> File Structure and Format: The following represents the file format used to  #> define ln.series. Note that the Field Numbers are for reference only; they do  #> not exist in the database. Data files are in ASCII text format. Data elements  #> are separated by tabs; the first record of each file contains the column headers  #> for the data elements stored in each field. Each record ends with a new line  #> character.  #>  #> Field #/Data Element	Length		Value(Example)		 #>  #> 1.  series_id		  varies	LNU04000000 #>  #> 	Description of the components in the series ID  #>  #> 2.  prefix		  2             LN #>  #> 3.  seasonal code	  1		U #>  #> 4.  series code		  8		04000000 #>  #> 		 #> In the LN database, series ID codes cannot be decoded to refer to specific data types by looking at  #> the value of different components of the series code. Series in the LN database have many characteristics  #> and representing them all within the series code would result in extremely long ID codes. The only meaningful  #> values are the initial positions where LNS identifies a seasonally adjusted series and LNU identifies a not  #> seasonally adjusted series. The other values in the series ID code cannot be broken down into meaningful  #> components. You must use the ln.series file to identify series. #>  #> Additional fields in the Series file correspond to each of the mapping files and  #> information about the period for which the data series are defined. #>  #> begin_year		  4		1947 #>  #> begin_period	  	  3		M13 #>  #> end_year		  4		2023 #>  #> end_period		  3		M10 #>  #>  #>  #>  #>  #> ================================================================================ #> Section 5 - Data file format and field definitions #> ================================================================================ #> Data File Structure and Format: The following represents the file format used to  #> define each data file. Note that the field numbers are for reference only; they  #> do not exist in the database. Data files are in ASCII text format. Data  #> elements are separated by tabs; the first record of each file contains the  #> column headers for the data elements stored in each field. Each record ends  #> with a new line character.  #>  #> The ln.data file is stored in one file:   #>  #> 	1.  ln.data.1.AllData	- All data #>  #> The above data file has the following format: #>  #> Field #/Data Element	Length		Value(Example)	 #>  #> 1. series_id		  varies	LNU04000000 #>  #> 2. year			   4		2023	 #>  #> 3. period		   3		M10	 #>  #> 4. value		  12		3.6	 #>  #> 5. footnote_codes	  10		It varies #>  #>  #> ================================================================================= #> Section 6 - Mapping file formats and field definitions #> ================================================================================= #> Mapping File Structure and Format: The following represents the file format used to  #> define each mapping file. Note that the field numbers are for reference only; they  #> do not exist in the database. Mapping files are in ASCII text format. Data elements  #> are separated by tabs. The first record of each file contains the column headers  #> for the data elements stored in each field. Each record ends with a new line character.  #>  #> Each mapping file follows a similar format: #>  #> Field #/Data Element		Length		Value (Example) #>  #> 1. characteristic code 		varies		varies #>  #> 2. characteristic text		varies		varies #>  #>  #> For example, the ln.ages mapping file contains #>  #> 1. ages_code			2		00 #>  #> 2. ages_text			17		16 years and over #>  #>  #>   #>  # }

what: Download Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data — get_ces
title: Download Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data — get_ces
text: function downloads Current Employment Statistics data Bureau Labor Statistics. data includes national, regional, state, substate employment statistics. default, available areas, data types, periods included.

title: Download Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data — get_ces
code: get_ces(   states = NULL,   industry_filter = NULL,   current_year_only = FALSE,   transform = TRUE,   monthly_only = TRUE,   simplify_table = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = TRUE,   return_diagnostics = FALSE )

title: Download Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data — get_ces
text: states Character vector state abbreviations download (e.g., c("MA", "NY", "CA")). specified, downloads states (industries, years). combined industry_filter current_year_only. Use `list_ces_states()` see available states. industry_filter Character string specifying industry category download. specified, downloads industry states (2007-present). combined states current_year_only. Use `list_ces_industries()` see available industry filters. current_year_only Logical. TRUE, downloads current year file contains states industries recent years (2006-present). combined states industry_filter. FALSE (default), uses parameters. transform Logical. TRUE (default), converts employment values thousands actual counts multiplying 1000 specific data types (codes 1, 6, 26) removes ", Thousands" data type labels. monthly_only Logical. TRUE (default), filters annual data (period M13). simplify_table Logical. TRUE (default), removes excess columns creates date column Year Period original data. suppress_warnings Logical. TRUE (default), suppress individual download warnings diagnostic messages cleaner output batch processing. FALSE, returns data prints warnings messages console. return_diagnostics Logical. FALSE (default), returns data. TRUE, returns full bls_data_collection object diagnostics.

title: Download Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data — get_ces
text: default, returns data.table CES data. return_diagnostics = TRUE,   returns bls_data_collection object containing data comprehensive diagnostics.

title: Download Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data — get_ces
text: **Performance Notes:** default behavior downloads large file (~500MB+) containing states industries, can take several minutes. faster downloads, consider: Use states = c("MA", "NY") download specific states Use industry_filter = "total_nonfarm" summary employment data Use current_year_only = TRUE recent data (2006-present) **State Codes:** Use standard two-letter state abbreviations (e.g., "MA", "CA", "NY"). Puerto Rico = "PR", Virgin Islands = "VI", District Columbia = "DC". **Industry Filters:** Available options include: "total_nonfarm" - Total non-farm employment summary "total_private" - Private sector totals (2007-present) "manufacturing" - Manufacturing sector (2007-present) "construction" - Construction sector (2007-present) "retail_trade" - Retail trade sector (2007-present) "government" - Government sector (2007-present) others - see BLS documentation full list

title: Download Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data — get_ces
code: # \donttest{ # Fast download: Massachusetts and Connecticut data only (all industries) ces_states <- get_ces(states = c("MA", "CT"))  # Fast download: Manufacturing data for all states ces_manufacturing <- get_ces(industry_filter = "manufacturing")  # Fast download: Current year data for all states and industries ces_current <- get_ces(current_year_only = TRUE)  # Complete dataset (slower - all states, industries, and years) ces_all <- get_ces() #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `value = as.numeric(value)`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! NAs introduced by coercion  # Download with full diagnostics if needed ces_result <- get_ces(states = "MA", return_diagnostics = TRUE) ces_data <- get_bls_data(ces_result)  # Check for download issues if (has_bls_issues(ces_result)) {   print_bls_warnings(ces_result) } #> CESData Download Warnings: #> ============================ #> Total files downloaded:7 #> Files with issues:1 #> Total warnings:2 #> Final data dimensions:210438 x 14 #>  #> Summary of warnings: #>   1. Series Metadata : Phantom columns detected and cleaned: 1 #>   2. Series Metadata : Empty columns removed: 1 #>  #> Run with return_diagnostics=TRUE and print_bls_warnings(data, detailed = TRUE) for file-by-file details # }

what: Download Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) Data — get_jolts
title: Download Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) Data — get_jolts
text: function downloads Job Openings Labor Turnover data U.S. Bureau Labor Statistics. JOLTS data provides insights job market dynamics including job openings, hires, separations, quits, layoffs. Data available national, regional, state levels various industry size class breakdowns.

title: Download Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) Data — get_jolts
code: get_jolts(   monthly_only = TRUE,   remove_regions = TRUE,   remove_national = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = TRUE,   return_diagnostics = FALSE )

title: Download Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) Data — get_jolts
text: monthly_only Logical. TRUE (default), excludes annual data (period M13) includes monthly observations. remove_regions Logical. TRUE (default), excludes regional aggregates (Midwest, Northeast, South, West) identified state codes MW, NE, , . remove_national Logical. TRUE (default), excludes national-level data (state code 00). Set FALSE include national data industry size class breakdowns. suppress_warnings Logical. TRUE (default), suppress individual download warnings diagnostic messages cleaner output batch processing. FALSE, returns data prints warnings messages console. return_diagnostics Logical. TRUE, returns bls_data_collection object full diagnostics. FALSE (default), returns just data table.

title: Download Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) Data — get_jolts
text: default, returns data.table JOLTS data. return_diagnostics = TRUE,   returns bls_data_collection object containing JOLTS data following key columns: series_id BLS series identifier year Year observation period Time period (M01-M12 months) value JOLTS statistic value (transformed based data type) date Date observation state_text State name dataelement_text Type JOLTS measure (job openings, hires, separations, etc.) area_text Geographic area description sizeclass_text Establishment size class industry_text Industry classification ratelevel_code Whether value "Level" (count) "Rate" (percentage) periodname Month name

title: Download Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) Data — get_jolts
text: function performs several data transformations: Converts rate values proportions (divides 100) except Unemployed Job Opening ratio. Converts level values actual counts (multiplies 1000) Creates proper date column year period Adds readable month names

title: Download Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) Data — get_jolts
code: # \donttest{ # Download state-level JOLTS data (default - returns data directly) jolts_data <- get_jolts()  # Include national data with industry breakdowns jolts_national <- get_jolts(remove_national = FALSE) #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `value = as.numeric(value)`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! NAs introduced by coercion  # Get full diagnostic object if needed jolts_with_diagnostics <- get_jolts(return_diagnostics = TRUE) print_bls_warnings(jolts_with_diagnostics) #> JOLTSData Download Warnings: #> ============================== #> Total files downloaded:7 #> Files with issues:1 #> Total warnings:2 #> Final data dimensions:318087 x 22 #>  #> Summary of warnings: #>   1. series : Phantom columns detected and cleaned: 1 #>   2. series : Empty columns removed: 1 #>  #> Run with return_diagnostics=TRUE and print_bls_warnings(data, detailed = TRUE) for file-by-file details  # View job openings by state for latest period job_openings <- jolts_data[dataelement_text == "Job openings" &                            date == max(date)] # }

what: Download Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) Data — get_laus
title: Download Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) Data — get_laus
text: function downloads Local Area Unemployment Statistics data U.S. Bureau  Labor Statistics. Due large size LAUS datasets (county city  files >300MB), users must specify geographic level download. function  provides access seasonally adjusted unadjusted data various geographic levels.  Additional datasets provide comprehensive non-seasonally-adjusted data areas broken  5-year increments

title: Download Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) Data — get_laus
code: get_laus(   geography = "state_adjusted",   monthly_only = TRUE,   transform = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = TRUE,   return_diagnostics = FALSE )

title: Download Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) Data — get_laus
text: geography Character string specifying geographic level adjustment type. Default "state_adjusted". Valid options : "state_current_adjusted" - Current seasonally adjusted state data "state_unadjusted" - historical unadjusted state data "state_adjusted" - historical seasonally adjusted state data (default) "region_unadjusted" - Unadjusted regional division data "region_adjusted" - Seasonally adjusted regional division data "metro" - Metropolitan statistical area data "division" - Division-level data "micro" - Micropolitan statistical area data "combined" - Combined statistical area data "county" - County-level data (large file >300MB) "city" - City town data (large file >300MB) "1990-1994" - Comprehensive unadjusted data 1990-1994 "1995-1999" - Comprehensive unadjusted data 1995-1999 "2000-2004" - Comprehensive unadjusted data 2000-2004 "2005-2009" - Comprehensive unadjusted data 2005-2009 "2010-2014" - Comprehensive unadjusted data 2010-2014 "2015-2019" - Comprehensive unadjusted data 2015-2019 "2020-2024" - Comprehensive unadjusted data 2020-2024 "2025-2029" - Comprehensive unadjusted data 2025-2029 "ST" - state two-character USPS abbreviation, plus DC PR monthly_only Logical. TRUE (default), excludes annual data (period M13) creates date column year period. transform Logical. TRUE (default), converts rate ratio measures percentages proportions dividing 100. Unemployment rates expressed decimals (e.g., 0.05 5% unemployment) rather whole numbers (e.g. 5). suppress_warnings Logical. TRUE (default), suppress individual download warnings diagnostic messages cleaner output batch processing. FALSE, returns data prints warnings messages console. return_diagnostics Logical. TRUE, returns bls_data_collection object full diagnostics. FALSE (default), returns just data table.

title: Download Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) Data — get_laus
text: default, returns data.table LAUS data. return_diagnostics = TRUE,   returns bls_data_collection object containing LAUS data following key columns: series_id BLS series identifier year Year observation period Time period (M01-M12 months, M13 annual) value Employment statistic value (transformed transform = TRUE) date Date observation (monthly_only = TRUE) area_text Geographic area name area_type_code Code indicating area type measure_text Type measure (unemployment rate, labor force, employment, etc.) seasonal Seasonal adjustment status

title: Download Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) Data — get_laus
text: function joins data multiple BLS files: Main data file (varies geography selection) Series definitions (la.series) Area codes names (la.area) Measure definitions (la.measure)

title: Download Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) Data — get_laus
code: # \donttest{ # Download state-level seasonally adjusted data (default operation) laus_states <- get_laus() #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `value = as.numeric(value)`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! NAs introduced by coercion  # View unemployment rates by state for latest period unemployment <- laus_states[grepl("unemployment rate", measure_text) & date == max(date)]  # Download unadjusted state data laus_states_unadjusted <- get_laus(geography = "state_unadjusted") #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `value = as.numeric(value)`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! NAs introduced by coercion  # Get full diagnostic object if needed laus_with_diagnostics <- get_laus(return_diagnostics = TRUE) #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `value = as.numeric(value)`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! NAs introduced by coercion print_bls_warnings(laus_with_diagnostics) #> No warnings forLAUSdata download   # }

what: Get National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data from BLS — get_national_ces
title: Get National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data from BLS — get_national_ces
text: function downloads processes national Current Employment Statistics (CES) data Bureau Labor Statistics (BLS). retrieves multiple related datasets joins together create comprehensive employment statistics dataset industry classifications, data types, time period information.

title: Get National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data from BLS — get_national_ces
code: get_national_ces(   dataset_filter = "all_data",   monthly_only = TRUE,   simplify_table = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = TRUE,   return_diagnostics = FALSE )

title: Get National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data from BLS — get_national_ces
text: dataset_filter Character string specifying dataset download. Options include: "all_data" (default) - Complete dataset series "current_seasonally_adjusted" - seasonally adjusted -employee series "real_earnings_all_employees" - Real earnings data employees "real_earnings_production" - Real earnings data production employees monthly_only Logical. TRUE (default), excludes annual averages (period "M13") returns monthly data. FALSE, includes periods including annual averages. simplify_table Logical. TRUE (default), removes several metadata columns (series_title, begin_year, begin_period, end_year, end_period, naics_code, publishing_status, display_level, selectable, sort_sequence) adds formatted date column. FALSE, returns full dataset available columns. suppress_warnings Logical. TRUE (default), suppresses download warnings diagnostics. FALSE, displays warning output diagnostic information. return_diagnostics Logical. TRUE, returns bls_data_collection object full diagnostics. FALSE (default), returns just data table.

title: Get National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data from BLS — get_national_ces
text: default, returns data.table CES data. return_diagnostics = TRUE,   returns bls_data_collection object containing data comprehensive diagnostics.

title: Get National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data from BLS — get_national_ces
text: function can download one four specialized national CES datasets based dataset_filter parameter: all_data: Complete dataset (ce.data.0.AllCESSeries) - contains entire     history series currently published CES program current_seasonally_adjusted: (ce.data.01a.CurrentSeasAE) - contains     every seasonally adjusted employee series complete history real_earnings_all_employees: (ce.data.02b.AllRealEarningsAE) - contains     real earnings data (1982-84 dollars) employees real_earnings_production: (ce.data.03c.AllRealEarningsPE) - contains     real earnings data (1982-84 dollars) production/nonsupervisory employees Additional metadata files always downloaded joined: ce.series - Series metadata ce.industry - Industry classifications ce.datatype - Data type definitions ce.period - Time period definitions ce.supersector - Supersector classifications datasets joined together provide context labels employment statistics. function uses enhanced `download_bls_files()` helper function robust downloads diagnostic reporting. Performance Note: Using specialized datasets ("all_data") can significantly reduce download time file size still providing comprehensive employment statistics.

title: Get National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data from BLS — get_national_ces
text: function requires following packages: dplyr, data.table, httr, lubridate (date formatting simplify_table=TRUE). `fread_bls()` `create_bls_object()` helper functions must available environment.

title: Get National Current Employment Statistics (CES) Data from BLS — get_national_ces
code: # \donttest{ # Get complete monthly CES data with simplified table structure (default) ces_monthly <- get_national_ces() #> Downloading national CES datasets (Complete national CES dataset)... #> Joining CES datasets... #> National CES data download complete! #> Dataset: Complete national CES dataset #> Final dataset dimensions: 7793626 x 14  # Get only seasonally adjusted data (faster download) ces_seasonal <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = "current_seasonally_adjusted") #> Downloading national CES datasets (Seasonally adjusted all-employee series)... #> Joining CES datasets... #> National CES data download complete! #> Dataset: Seasonally adjusted all-employee series #> Final dataset dimensions: 392253 x 14  # Get real earnings data for all employees ces_real_earnings <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = "real_earnings_all_employees") #> Downloading national CES datasets (Real earnings for all employees)... #> Joining CES datasets... #> National CES data download complete! #> Dataset: Real earnings for all employees #> Final dataset dimensions: 514016 x 14  # Get all data including annual averages with full metadata ces_full <- get_national_ces(dataset_filter = "all_data",                              monthly_only = FALSE, simplify_table = FALSE) #> Downloading national CES datasets (Complete national CES dataset)... #> Joining CES datasets... #> National CES data download complete! #> Dataset: Complete national CES dataset #> Final dataset dimensions: 8106467 x 23  # Get data with warnings and diagnostic information displayed ces_with_warnings <- get_national_ces(suppress_warnings = FALSE) #> Downloading national CES datasets (Complete national CES dataset)... #> Downloadingdata... #> Downloadingseries... #> Downloadingindustry... #> Downloadingperiod... #> Downloadingdatatype... #> Downloadingsupersector... #> Joining CES datasets... #> No warnings forNational CES: Complete national CES datasetdata download #> National CES data download complete! #> Dataset: Complete national CES dataset #> Final dataset dimensions: 7793626 x 14  # Get full diagnostic object if needed data_with_diagnostics <- get_national_ces(return_diagnostics = TRUE) #> Downloading national CES datasets (Complete national CES dataset)... #> Joining CES datasets... #> National CES data download complete! #> Dataset: Complete national CES dataset #> Final dataset dimensions: 7793626 x 14 print_bls_warnings(data_with_diagnostics) #> No warnings forNational CES: Complete national CES datasetdata download # }

what: Download Occupational Employment and Wage Statistics (OEWS) Data — get_oews
title: Download Occupational Employment and Wage Statistics (OEWS) Data — get_oews
text: function downloads joins together occupational employment wage data Bureau Labor Statistics OEWS program. data includes employment wage estimates occupation geographic area. Note OEWS large data set (6 million rows), require longer download.

title: Download Occupational Employment and Wage Statistics (OEWS) Data — get_oews
code: get_oews(   simplify_table = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = TRUE,   return_diagnostics = FALSE,   fast_read = TRUE )

title: Download Occupational Employment and Wage Statistics (OEWS) Data — get_oews
text: simplify_table Logical.  TRUE (default), remove columns result internal BLS references can derived elements table. suppress_warnings Logical. TRUE (default), suppress individual download warnings diagnostic messages cleaner output batch processing. FALSE, returns data prints warnings messages console. return_diagnostics Logical. TRUE, returns bls_data_collection object full diagnostics. FALSE (default), returns just data table. fast_read Logical.  TRUE (default), derives lookup values directly series_id avoid reading series file, speed download process. fast_read, data can download 17 seconds (depending bandwidth).  Without fast_read, download takes 57 seconds.

title: Download Occupational Employment and Wage Statistics (OEWS) Data — get_oews
text: default, returns data.table OEWS data. return_diagnostics = TRUE,   returns bls_data_collection object containing data comprehensive diagnostics. columns returned data frame `simplify_table = TRUE` listed .  Unless otherwise specified, data returned character string preserve value leading trailing zeroes. series_id - unique OEWS series identifier. year - year estimate refers.  OEWS time series data, always recent year. value - Numeric. value given data type, given area, given industry occupation. seasonal - Whether data seasonally adjusted. areatype_code - Code representing type area (National ("N"), Statewide ("S"), Local ("M")). industry_code - NAICS code industry. occupation_code - SOC code occupation. Description given occupation_name. datatype_code - Lookup code data type given row.  Description given datatype_name. state_code - Two-digit FIPS code state. area_code - unique OEWS code substate area. Description given area_name. series_title - Descriptive title full series ID. occupation_name - text description occupation. occupation_description - detailed description tasks associated occupation. area_name - text description area. datatype_name - text description type data represented `value`.

title: Download OEWS Area Definitions — get_oews_areas
text: Download OEWS Area Definitions

title: Download OEWS Area Definitions — get_oews_areas
code: get_oews_areas(ref_year, silent = TRUE, geometry = TRUE)

title: Download OEWS Area Definitions — get_oews_areas
text: ref_year Four-digit year (converted integer). year retrieve OEWS area definitions. Valid values 2024 current release year. Prior years included Township codes, change structure file. silent Logical. TRUE (default), suppress console output geometry Logical.  TRUE (default), downloads shapefiles OEWS area definitions using `tigris::counties()` `tigris::shift_geometry()` render Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico focus area continental United States.

title: Download OEWS Area Definitions — get_oews_areas
text: Data table maps individual counties OEWS area definitions. fips_code - State FIPS code state_name - state name state_abb - state two-character postal abbreviation oews_area_code - OEWS area code defining metropolitan area nonmetropolitan area county belongs . oews_area_name - OEWS area name county_code - FIPS code county county_name - county name

title: Download OEWS Area Definitions — get_oews_areas
code: # \donttest{  # Get OEWS area definitions without shapefiles and with processing messages.  test <- get_oews_areas(ref_year = 2024, geometry = FALSE, silent = FALSE) #> Downloading OEWS area definitions from BLS. #> Processing OEWS area definition Excel file for 2024.   # }

title: Get QCEW Data Slices — get_qcew
text: function pulls data BLS QCEW Open Data Access CSV Data Slices. iterates specified years quarters (annual data) retrieve industry-specific area-specific data tables merges single data.table. Optionally, joins internal package lookup tables industry area descriptions.

title: Get QCEW Data Slices — get_qcew
code: get_qcew(   period_type = "quarter",   year_start = NULL,   year_end = NULL,   industry_code = NULL,   area_code = NULL,   add_lookups = TRUE,   silently = FALSE )

title: Get QCEW Data Slices — get_qcew
text: period_type Character. Either "quarter" "year". Defaults "quarter". year_start Numeric. first year retrieve data . Defaults year date 6 months prior current system date. year_end Numeric. last year retrieve data . Defaults year date 6 months prior current system date. industry_code Character. NAICS industry code (e.g., "10", "31-33"). Constructs URL Industry Data Slice. Mutually exclusive `area_code`. area_code Character. QCEW area code (e.g., "US000", "32000", "C2982"). Constructs URL Area Data Slice. Mutually exclusive `industry_code`. add_lookups Logical. TRUE, joins package's ind_lookup area_lookup tables results provide descriptive labels. Defaults TRUE. silently Logical. TRUE, suppresses status messages URLs accessed. Defaults FALSE.

title: Get QCEW Data Slices — get_qcew
text: combined data.table containing requested QCEW data, optionally merged lookup columns   calculated date column.  data layout different quarterly annual data files set `period_type` argument. Quarterly files: area_fips - Character. Area code row.  Included `area_lookup` data file contains mapping information. industry_code - Character. NAICS, Supersector, Cluster, Total Industries code. Numeric characters string preserve examining structure heirarchy. own_code - Integer.  Values 0-5 designate ownership. See definitions https://www.bls.gov/cew/classifications/ownerships/ownership-titles.htm agglvl_code - Integer.   Two digit code identifying level aggregation.  See definitons https://www.bls.gov/cew/classifications/aggregation/agg-level-titles.htm size_code - Integer. Single-digit code representing size establishments. See definitions https://www.bls.gov/cew/classifications/size/size-titles.htm year Integer.  Four-digit calendar year returned data. qtr Integer. calendar quarter data. disclosure_code Character.  Values either blank string "N".  Values N disclose employment wages maintain confidentiality. qtryly_estabs Integer.  number business establishments (worksites) industry area quarter. month1_emplvl Integer. Employment first month quarter (January, April, July, October). month2_emplvl Integer. Employment second month quarter (February, May, August, November). month3_emplvl Integer. Employment third month quarter (March, June, September, December). total_qtrly_wages Ingeger64. Total wages paid quarter. taxable_qtrly_wages Ingeger64. Wages subject unemployment insurance (UI) taxes quarter.  Note - wages subject UI vary state follow different seasonal patterns result. qtrly_contributions Integer. UI taxes (Contributions) paid employers quarter. Note - UI tax policy varies state. avg_wkly_wage Integer. Average weekly wage quarter (Total wages divided average employment, divided 13). lq_disclosure_code Character.  Blank "N".  Values "N" suppress location quotient data confidentiality. lq_qtrly_estabs Numeric. Location quotient establishments relative U.S. lq_month1_emplvl Numeric. Location quotient month 1 employment relative U.S. lq_month2_emplvl Numeric. Location quotient month 2 employment relative U.S. lq_month3_emplvl Numeric. Location quotient month 3 employment relative U.S. lq_total_qtrly_wages Numeric. Location quotient total wages relative U.S. lq_taxable_qtrly_wages Numeric. Location quotient taxable quarterly wages relative U.S. lq_qtrly_contributions Numeric. Location quotient quarterly UI taxes paid relative U.S. lq_avg_wkly_wage Numeric. Location quotient average weekly wages relative U.S. oty_disclosure_code Character.  Blank "N".  Values "N" suppress --year data confidentiality. oty_qtrly_estabs_chg Numeric. --year change establishments. oty_qtrly_estabs_pct_chg Numeric. --year percent change establishments. oty_month1_emplvl_chg Numeric. --year change month 1 employment. oty_month1_emplvl_pct_chg Numeric. --year percent change month 1 employment. oty_month2_emplvl_chg Numeric. --year change month 2 employment. oty_month2_emplvl_pct_chg Numeric. --year percent change month 2 employment. oty_month3_emplvl_chg Numeric. --year change month 3 employment. oty_month3_emplvl_pct_chg Numeric. --year percent change month 3 employment. oty_total_qtrly_wages_chg Numeric. --year change total wages. oty_total_qtrly_wages_pct_chg Numeric. --year percent change total wages. oty_taxable_qtrly_wages_chg Numeric. --year change taxable quarterly wages. oty_taxable_qtrly_wages_pct_chg Numeric. --year percent change taxable quarterly wages. oty_qtrly_contributions_chg Numeric. --year change quarterly UI taxes paid. oty_qtrly_contributions_pct_chg Numeric. --year percent change quarterly UI taxes paid. oty_avg_wkly_wage_chg Numeric. --year change average weekly wages. oty_avg_wkly_wage_pct_chg Numeric. --year percent change average weekly wages. date Date. Calculated calendar date based year quarter.  Reflects first day quarter. industry_title Character. Added based industry_code ind_level Character. Description level aggregation based industry_code. naics_2d Character. First two characters industry_code, useful identifying industries. sector Character. Similar naics_2d, industries like Manufacturing multiple two digit NAICS codes, span groupings, example "31-33" vintage_start. Integer. Calendar year earliest vintage industry_code. NAICS codes updated every 5 years.  using industry codes date, titles may exist may incorrect. vintage_end. Integer. Calendar year last year industry code used.  Years point contain industry code.  Set 3000 current data. area_title Character.  Area description based area_fips provided BLS. area_type Character. Description type area based area_title. consistent naming grouping BLS data. stfips Character. two-digit FIPS code state containing given area. Set "00" multi-state regions. specified_region. Either two-character US Postal Service abbreviation state containing area hyphenated list codes multi-state areas. Annual files: area_fips - Character. Area code row.  Included `area_lookup` data file contains mapping information. industry_code - Character. NAICS, Supersector, Cluster, Total Industries code. Numeric characters string preserve examining structure heirarchy. own_code - Integer.  Values 0-5 designate ownership. See definitions https://www.bls.gov/cew/classifications/ownerships/ownership-titles.htm agglvl_code - Integer.   Two digit code identifying level aggregation.  See definitons https://www.bls.gov/cew/classifications/aggregation/agg-level-titles.htm size_code - Integer. Single-digit code representing size establishments. See definitions https://www.bls.gov/cew/classifications/size/size-titles.htm year Integer.  Four-digit calendar year returned data. qtr Character. Set "" represent annual data. disclosure_code Character.  Values either blank string "N".  Values N disclose employment wages maintain confidentiality. annual_avg_estabs Integer.  average number business establishments (worksites) industry area year. annual_avg_emplvl Integer. average monthly employment level given year. total_annual_wages Ingeger64. Total wages paid year. taxable_annual_wages Ingeger64. Wages subject unemployment insurance (UI) taxes year.  Note - wages subject UI vary state follow different seasonal patterns result. annual_contributions Integer. UI taxes (Contributions) paid employers year. Note - UI tax policy varies state. annual_avg_wkly_wage Integer. Average weekly wage year (Total wages divided average employment, divided 52). avg_annual_pay Integer. Average annual pay year. lq_disclosure_code Character.  Blank "N".  Values "N" suppress location quotient data confidentiality. lq_annual_avg_estabs Numeric. Location quotient establishments relative U.S. lq_annual_avg_emplvl Numeric. Location quotient annual employment relative U.S. lq_total_annual_wages Numeric. Location quotient total wages relative U.S. lq_taxable_annual_wages Numeric. Location quotient taxable annual wages relative U.S. lq_annual_contributions Numeric. Location quotient annual UI taxes paid relative U.S. lq_annual_avg_wkly_wage Numeric. Location quotient average weekly wages relative U.S. lq_avg_annual_pay Numeric. title: Get QCEW Data Slices — get_qcew

what: NAICS Industry Titles Lookup Table (QCEW) — ind_lookup
title: NAICS Industry Titles Lookup Table (QCEW) — ind_lookup
text: data frame containing structure North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) titles codes used U.S. Bureau Labor Statistics (BLS), including Quarterly Census Employment Wages (QCEW) program. data current 2022 NAICS revision. table primarily used internally `BLSloadR` functions add human-readable industry titles define valid industry lookups.

title: NAICS Industry Titles Lookup Table (QCEW) — ind_lookup
code: data(ind_lookup)

title: NAICS Industry Titles Lookup Table (QCEW) — ind_lookup
text: data frame 2678 rows 7 columns: industry_code - Character.  NAICS industry code.  Items starting 10 aggregated values, corresponding unique 6-digit NAICS. industry_title - Character. descripion industry code provided BLS.  title also includes code value clarity. ind_level - Character. description level aggregation. Values "Total", "Cluster", "Supersector" "10" code aggregations, else length NAICS code, 2-6 digits. naics_2d - Character. first two digits `industry_code`, may helpful filter results. sector - Character.  Similar `naics_2d` except industry sector spans multiple two digit codes, codes hyphenated (e.g. Manufacturing NAICS 31, 32, 33, displays '31-33'). vintage_start - Integer.  earliest year reviewed NAICS code use. NAICS change every 5 years, data year missing values. vintage_end - Integer. last year particular code used, applicable. Set 3000 current codes.

title: NAICS Industry Titles Lookup Table (QCEW) — ind_lookup
text: https://www.bls.gov/cew/classifications/industry/industry-titles.htm

title: NAICS Industry Titles Lookup Table (QCEW) — ind_lookup
text: NAICS structure hierarchical. Codes typically longer detailed industries.

title: NAICS Industry Titles Lookup Table (QCEW) — ind_lookup
code: # Load the lookup table data(ind_lookup)  # Find the industry title for NAICS 51 (Information) ind_lookup[ind_lookup$industry_code == "51", ] #> # A tibble: 1 × 7 #>   industry_code industry_title       ind_level     naics_2d sector vintage_start #>   <chr>         <chr>                <chr>         <chr>    <chr>          <int> #> 1 51            NAICS 51 Information NAICS 2-digit 51       51              2022 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: vintage_end <int>  # Get the supersector codes supersectors <- ind_lookup[ind_lookup$ind_level == "Supersector", ]  # Get all 3-digit NAICS codes in the Manufacturing industry mfg_codes <- ind_lookup |>  dplyr::filter(sector == "31-33" & ind_level == "NAICS 3-digit")

title: Generic BLS Dataset Download — load_bls_dataset
text: function generalizes method download BLS data given time series database. files accessed https://download.bls.gov/pub/time.series/ several datasets available. summary identified database can generated using `bls_overiew()` function. multiple potential data files exist (common large data sets), function prompt input file use.

title: Generic BLS Dataset Download — load_bls_dataset
code: load_bls_dataset(   database_code,   return_full = FALSE,   simplify_table = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = FALSE )

title: Generic BLS Dataset Download — load_bls_dataset
text: database_code two digit character identifier desired database. Valid options : "ce" - National Current Employment Statistics Data "sm" - State Metro area Current Employment Statistics Data "mp" - Major Sector Total Factor Productivity "ci" - Employment Cost Index "eb" - Employee Benefits Survey return_full argument defaults FALSE. set TRUE return list elements data retrieved BLS separating data, series, mapping values downloaded. simplify_table parameter defaults TRUE. TRUE remove columns date "_code" column name, well series internal identifiers provide general information series needed performing time series analysis. parameter also converts column "value" numeric generates date column year period columns data. suppress_warnings Logical. TRUE, suppress individual download warnings processing.

title: Generic BLS Dataset Download — load_bls_dataset
text: function return either bls_data_collection object (return_full FALSE provided)  named list returned data including bls_data_collection object.

title: Generic BLS Dataset Download — load_bls_dataset
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Download Employer Cost Index Data cost_index <- load_bls_dataset("ci")  # Download separated data, series, and mapping columns benefits <- load_bls_dataset("eb", return_full = TRUE)  # Download data without removing excess columns and value conversions productivity <- load_bls_dataset("mp", simplify_table = FALSE)  # Check for download issues if (has_bls_issues(cost_index)) {   print_bls_warnings(cost_index, detailed = TRUE) } } # }

Specific states (all industries, all years) #>   ces_states <- get_ces(states = c('MA', 'NY', 'CT')) #>  #>   # Specific industry (all states, 2007-present) #>   ces_manufacturing <- get_ces(industry_filter = 'manufacturing') #>  #>   # Current year data (all states and industries, 2006-present) #>   ces_current <- get_ces(current_year_only = TRUE) #>  #>   # Complete dataset (all states, industries, and years - slowest) #>   ces_all <- get_ces() #>  #> Performance: Filtering reduces download time by 50-90% vs. full dataset! #> Note: Parameters are mutually exclusive - choose only one filtering option.

what: Enhanced CES Functions with Performance Filtering
title: BLSloadR 0.3.0
text: states parameter: Download data specific states (90%+ faster full download) industry_filter parameter: Focus specific industries (retail_trade, manufacturing, etc.) current_year_only parameter: Get recent data (2006-present) instead complete history Mutually exclusive filtering prevents conflicting options dataset_filter parameter 4 options: all_data, current_seasonally_adjusted, real_earnings_all_employees, real_earnings_production 95% faster downloads specialized datasets Enhanced documentation performance notes Get quarterly annual data one year multiple years. Append area industry definitions data. QCEW represents highly detailed data across counties, combined areas, states national regions. Includes detailed employment wage data.

title: BLSloadR 0.3.0
text: list_ces_states() - List available states filtering list_ces_industries() - List available industry filters descriptions show_ces_options() - Comprehensive usage guide CES options list_national_ces_options() - List national dataset filter options show_national_ces_options() - Usage guide national CES datasets area_lookup data table details QCEW area codes pre-filter data requests. ind_lookup data table details NAICS codes used QCEW files.

title: BLSloadR 0.3.0
text: Fixed URL parameter passing download_bls_files() (downloads[[‘key’]] vs downloads$key) Consistent parameter naming across functions (suppress_warnings instead mixed naming) Enhanced error handling validation throughout Improved diagnostic messaging user feedback
